business.categories: Chinese, Noodles, Restaurants, Seafood

reviews.text:
Came here after a not so great customer service experience at another spot nearby and was pleasantly granted a table without reservation for a group of 8.

I really enjoyed the mixed seafood + bean curd soup and dry-fried beef chow fun. Also, can't go wrong with fried rice, duck, and Chinese broccoli at a spot like this.

It's your typical family styled Chinese dining with the glass spinning centerpiece table. Service was quick as we came just before the dinner service picked up. Overall had a great experience. Would come again!

Drove through Philly before heading back to NY and stopped by Chinatown.  Decided to come give this place a try for family style meal.  There was maybe a less than 5 minute wait for a table for 4 on a Saturday at around 6ish.  We were seated at the first table closest to the entrance.  All of the tables were separated by partitions almost like you're in your own box area which was set up for COVID dining.  There's also a clear shower type curtain - think they utilized that more during height of pandemic.  There are about a total of 8 tables on the main floor - I think they also have an upstairs area with more space.
We ordered the west lake beef soup, lobster with sticky rice, pea shoots, and lamb casserole pot.  The soup was on the blander side and didn't have much flavor.  The beef in the soup kind of tasted like that fake lunch meat.  Overall both food and service was ok.

It's a little confusing how you go about getting seated here but once you figure that out order anything. We had the crispy seafood noodles, stewed pork belly and Peking pork chops and all 3 were fantastic. Served fast, steaming hot and absolutely delicious.

This place offers a variety of food. This review is specifically for these 2 dishes- shark fin soup and abalone. These didn't impress me much to be honest, a bit to salty to me. I would come back to try other dishes but definitely not these two haha. 

Service is OK compare to other restaurants in China town!!

I do not recommend this restaurant to ANY Chinese fellow folks, if you want to be treated as a customer or at least a person with some dignity. Their service is rude to an almost discriminating extent. 

We walked in as a small group on a weekday evening. We ordered 3 dishes and about 6:30pm all three dishes were ready and delivered to our table. About 7:30pm, multiple waiter/waitress started rushing us. It began with something small and gentle as offering to take away any finished dishes, btw none of the dishes were finished yet. And we were literately still eating. Then it escalated to offering the sweet porridge as desert. Then, dropping the check on the table without being asked. Then the owner even started collecting the dishes. Despite we told them every time we were not finished. And through the entire time, there were more than one tables unoccupied, and there were nobody waiting outside the restaurant. 

Finally we decided not worth ruining a good reunion and paid the check with 15-20% tip. When the waitress collected the signed check, she literally laid all the signed receipts side by side on the table in front us and checked each tip line to make sure we paid or at least paid enough tip. You could tell because she pointed her pen to each tip line for a couple second and probably run the math in her head. This is very insulting to be honest ... as a customer to be "rushed out" and then checked for our math (or gratitude)? 

One of my friends said .. oh they do that because some chinese do not tip. One, I believe most of chinese people do tip. Second, maybe the ones fresh off the boat dont understand how waiter/waitress get paid in US, then please explain to them and I believe they would be understanding. Third, if this is a real problem, maybe you should consider move the restaurant out of chinatown and renovate the place to target Americans. Fourth, and most important, if you require the customer to play American customs by paying tip, then please also follow the practice that -- gratitude needs to be earned --it's not regulated by any law that customer need to tip especially when you kick them out before they actually finish their meal!   

So, I will not return to that restaurant ... and do not recommend any chinese people do. What could be worse than being discriminated by your own kind?!

Today's lunch: Tai Lake Restaurant. 

Dim sum and a bowl of Abalone Congee. 

I've never had an Abalone Congee before. I was curious to try this congee. It's cold as winter in Philly (in late April 2021), and I needed something to warm me up. The service was great, I was greeted well and sat immediately. The server provided an ample amount of time to let me get situated before taking my order. Prior to my order, the server brought hot tea and water to the table. The servers were so attentive. Loved the service. I definitely will be back to try other menu items. 

The only thing I didn't like about the congee are the chicken with bones on. For me, it kinda made it a bit challenging. However, the Abalone was tender and the flavor of the congee was amazing. I'm eager to try the lobster congee . 

I also ordered the Sautéed Choy Sum and General Tso chicken for takeaway, which tasted amazing. 

If you're ever in Philly, try this place. Located in Chinatown on Cherry and 10th. They have a nice setting and follow covid protocols.
Didn't eat there...just saw it in the show King of Queens...must be good...it's been there for a long time

One of the well known go-to spots in Chinatown. Tai Lake offers a broad menu of classic Chinese dishes, specializing in fresh seafood. It's a good sign when you see so many Asian families having their gatherings there.

I've tried so many different items, and they're all good. Clams in black bean sauce, salt & pepper pork, salt & pepper squid, steamed fish, barbecue scallop, stir-fried noodles, salty fish fried rice, honey walnut shrimp, scallion and ginger lobster, fish filet with corn sauce, seafood in bird's nest. The list goes on. You'll be going back for more!

Great food, specially their beef noodles it was delicious...
it's better to make a reservation to avoid the waiting time

We've come here close to 30 times over the past 20 years or so. The quality of food is pretty good and this is my family's go-to place for seafood. With anything seafood, it can be quite costly but Asians love our Seafood don't we?

Tai Lake. I've eaten here countless times, sometimes a little intoxicated. I would say Tai Lake is a solid Chinese restaurant and they are open until 3am on weekends. This is one of the go to spots in Chinatown to eat after you're done your weekend late night activities.

Tai Lake gets packed, late on weekends, but it is efficient. The wait is not long as people just go in and out. Service is fast. The menu is huge but you can get a variety of dishes. I personally like the duck, fish maw soup, walnut shrimp but I pretty much can eat most things on the seemingly endless menu.
My favorite late spot in Chinatown, the staff are great and they always make you feel welcomed kinda, but the food really hits the spot after a night of dancing and drinking

Food is good. Waiter was nice and attentive. The fried rice and snow pea leaves with garlic were delicious. My only complaint is about atmosphere.
We were the only customers at the restaurant around 6 pm on a friday. Nearby, there were 2 tables of loud staff who were also having dinner. Inappropriate! Keep your staff separate from your customers.

I have been coming here for years with my family. Food have always been fresh. Services was always okay but all it matters was the food was good. And I love the fact that they have fresh seafood that you can choose

I'm not from the area and decided to have dinner here with my son.  There was about a 20 minute wait and we were asked to "order our food" at the counter prior to being seated which I found odd.  After we got our table, we were rushed to order.  We had a bottle of wine and an appetizer which came out at the same time as dinner.  After we finished, we were talking and finishing our wine and the server placed the check on the table.  As we continued to talk, the manager came to our table and asked us to leave!  Said there were other people waiting.  I couldn't believe it.  There was actually one couple who had just walked in the door.  After further observation, I realized that tables were quickly given to the "chinese" customers and others were treated differently and made to wait.  Upon leaving, I approached the manager and told him that I did not appreciate the way he pushed us out and that it was rude.  He did not apologize and stated "there were other people waiting" and walked away. As we exited the door, another gentleman was also waiting who stated that he had been waiting for awhile and the manager took another "chinese" couple ahead of him and seated them.  The manager also asked the gentlemen to "eat in the lobby".  The only good thing about this restaurant is the food, but customers service is horrible and appears to be borderline discrimination.   
Huge disappointment.  Will not return.

We ended up here after attempting to get late night dim sum and walking around Chinatown disappointed in what was still open. This place was packed at 11pm but they turned tables over quickly and we only waited for 5-10 minutes. Service was fast and the restaurant is very loud like most Chinese restaurants. We ended up getting a half order of duck, sweet and sour pork and a fried tofu dish. Everything was tasty but we were also starving. The duck wasn't fatty and the skin was super crispy. It came with these shrimp chips which were very stale and kinda weird presentation in general. They also gave a small portion of scallions but we just asked for more with any problem. My favorite was the fried tofu which is probably deep fried but the inside is still the soft silky type of tofu and there's a small shrimp stuffed on top- never had this before but would get it again! 

Nothing blew me away but I would recommend as a solid option in Chinatown especially late at night. Also just read that this is Nick Elmi's go to in Chinatown!
Good food and quick service! The duck was really good and crispy. Definitely would come back and recommend to friends and family.

4/5 after two visits with quite satisfying results
3.5/5 for food, 4/5 for service, ambience, cleanliness, credit card/dessert

Setting: I came with 2 groups on 2 separate occasions: with 6 and with 4 of us. We were promptly seated and given water/tea.

Ambience: Not too crowded, the noise level was acceptable

Service: Attentive, would suggest dishes of what to get, prompt

Food: 
-Snowpeas - great taste, a lovely green dish, classic Chinese
-Crispy skin chicken with shrimp chips - I got this dish twice and I think the first time was better, it's got good flavor with a fun balance of salt/pepper/texture and amount of meat per bone - 1/2 size chicken is sufficient
-Beijing Pork chops - sweet and meaty, could have done without this dish
-Seafood pan-fried noodles - I think other restaurants like M Kee do it better, the overall taste of the seafood is something to be desired, the noodles are nicely crisp with a balance of the sauce
-Fried seafood mix with calamari - Something where you can't really go wrong, might be a simple crowd pleaser if you're ever unsure what to order
-Pepper steak - meat was a bit too chewy
-Dessert: Orange slices and the second time we got some type of sweet soup with tapioca pearls, such a lovely way to end the meal

Tips/Takeaways:
-Nicer ambience than most other Chinatown restaurants, not too loud, good lighting and A/C, has an okay bathroom
-Snowpeas, Crispy-skin chicken
-Would recommend return for larger groups for the overall ambience, maybe every 6 months
Great place to go for late night post drinking Chinese food. Clean and great service. I enjoyed their Lo mein and singapore noodles! Delicious!

We want to eat some seafood so we walked in, they have 3 kinds of live shrimps, We ordered the cheapest one yet it is very expensive to me, $30 a pound, but we really like boiled shrimp with soysauce and green pepper rings dipping sauce（白灼虾). the shrimps are sooo great, taste freshly sweet. No offence, but I think storebuy Jumbo peeled and deveined headless frozen shrimps has no soul (spanish dish garlic shrimp is an exception)If you think the same way with me you have to treat yourself with it！
Avoid to order 红烧斑楠煲（fish belly clay pot) I like this dish, I always order it when I see it on menu but always disappointed, either they are using basa fillet or fried fish, come on! fried breaded seafood is garbage, waste seafood！

Tai Lake is my family's go to place for when we go out to eat and it looks like it is a very popular place among others as well. We always get the stir fry lobster with scallion and ginger, seafood rolls, coconut walnut shrimp, stir fry crabs with minced pork, and beef short ribs and it never disappoints. Try their pina colada. The complementary desert ( the sweet bean soup thing ??) always makes me want more.

We have had mixed visits.
Tonight was just mediocre.
Pan fried dumplings were over cooker outside and lukewarm inside.

Sorry
Ditto

We went there early evening. There wasn't any waiting.

We ordered fried fish, steamed fished, fried squid salt and pepper, Peking duck, clam with black bean sauce, and 2 veggies dish.

My favorites were the two vegetable dishes that we ordered.

Steamed bamboo fish seemed like it was over-cooked or not fresh. We barely touch any

Fried squid was under-seasoning 

So overall, we are not a bug fan. Probably will not go back

Hands down my favorite Chinese seafood restaurant in China Town
Their fried rice is always so good. Their ginger scallion lobster is a MUST TRY! So good and very worth the money. The lobster pieces are hefty pieces and tastes really good with the sauce. The duck there is also very good and is a must 
We also got the crispy fish rolls? That was good and perfectly crisp 
The service there is also excellent! The waiters there are friendly and helpful

Let's take a trip to Chinatown!!!! I really love this place. Cantonese seafood dishes are their specialty. With dine in and take out, this place is perfect for a family dinner or late night excursions. This is one of my favorite spots in Chinatown.

business.name: Square on Square

reviews.text:
I have been here twice,  2 months ago. They're not bad. I wish they know what is spicy. SmH LoL I came in to order, General tso's chicken. I asked for extra spicy and extra crispy. The person that took my order said. No problem extra spicy and extra crispy. When I got my order, that I requested. I was so happy I rushed home just to have it. Womp womp, I felt like it didn't hit the mark of what I expected to be. It fall in the line of, mild. SmH  I wasn't impressed. It o.k , but not great. 

On a good note, my brother who live in, Philadelphia. Said, to me that they have good seafood dishes . He like the honey walnut shrimp and seafood & vegetable and pan-fried noodles. He said, it good.

Yay, I wish their version of spicy was , spicy. Especially when I ask for EXTRA spicy. SmH

Once again, if your expecting spicy. Have your OWN pepper sauce or hot sauce, to make that happen. LoL ... I'm just saying ... LoL
Food quality has sunk to unacceptable low since they moved from chestnut st, plain and simple.  Avoid and pick someplace else.

We had a good experience with our delivery order tonight. The food arrived quickly and everything was tasty, especially the pork fried rice and wonton soup. A couple of the dishes were lacking a bit of flavor and had too much sauce for our liking, so removing a star for that. We were also a bit confused by the chicken and broccoli with garlic sauce, as it seemed more sweet/spicy than garlicky. Maybe it was a mistake? We ate it anyway. Overall we were satisfied and will likely order again!

Square on Square is not reliable with the quality of their entries. I have been eating there for over 20 years and their have been disappointment 20% of the time. No quality control, and don't expect any refund. Just had the Cold 
Sesame Noodles and it had a wonderful peanut tasting sauce that 15 years ago was thick and plentiful. Now, is it too lightly sauced and tonight's order had a clear taste of vinegar and not good at all. But for the price, you must expect bad orders, I guess. The original premises that Steven, back when he opened -that the chef had a unique and recognized credentials- is a thing of myth today.  So even if their are entrees that you like...the quality is not consistent and mediocre food has become more regular. JBK
Great food, pickup may be slow but all in all great. If you live in the area I recommend going here.

As a long time diner at Square on Square from its location at 19th an Chestnut to its current location on South 20th Street
I am hesitant of reviewing my most latest takeout order. However, I was successful in ordering the Orange Beef (not always available) and it was not up to par with prior takeout orders. For $19 it had very little meat and was covered with sauce and stuff and not good. The reliability is not always the same - some great nights and some mediocre to disappointing nights. I know finding workers willing to stay on for 6 months is difficult. It is really the luck of the draw...if you experience of good meal, remember what you ordered so to increase you chances of satisfaction again, however, there is no guarantee. Too many outdated websites and menu listing's  not available. Steven needs to offer fewer entrees so as to increase the quality. Not all listed items are worth be continued. Not sure this concern will even make a difference as he is expanding with MORE while giving to little attention to existing problems.

Oh my god, this was really awful. I ordered the beef chow fun with black bean. It was so salty it was inedible. Beneath the salt was a goopy sugar syrup base. I wanted to like this place, since it's so close to my new place, but this was really horrible.  The mushrooms were obviously from a jar or can. Beneath the salted sugar sauce was a few hidden pieces of beef floating  without flavor.
Never again, this was embarrassingly bad.

First, this was a bad I idea when I seen caucasian people acting crazy downtown with this place of business. I, place a order 34.95, did not get all of my order items. I did not get my sauces that was needed for my food. I ask for eight chicken wings, they chop up four wings in half, and said that's eight wings. Smfh! This place is the worse. I will stay with my black business owners going forward

Placed an order and it was cancelled after 20 min because "they were busy".   They've been late before a few times.   Get more delivery folks or stop offering delivery if you can't keep up with demand.

First time back for takeout since the pandemic started and it was GREAT. I ordered Won Ton Soup, Spring Rolls, and Shrimp in Wine Sauce and they were all delicious! I ordered with the Ritual app and the order was on time to the very minute and fresh and the service was excellent.
I order from here all the time. Food is fresh and great, they always say 45 minutes for delivery but usually gets here in 15. Not even sure how it's possible but it's awesome.

I loved Square for years and have raved about it to many friends and colleagues. The change in location aside, the service and quality of food have changed dramatically. After several large order mishaps and bad customer support or offers to remedy I simply cannot give them any more business. There are far too many restaurants to be subjected to poor service and food quality particularly after so many years of loyalty.

We've gone to square on square for years as we lived above it before it moved and love the new location even more. Unfortunately, something has really changed. We ordered the other night and after over an hour with no delivery, we called just to check on the status. The person who answered didn't take our name or number or even say hello, just asked did we already place an order, we said "Yes" and they replied "its on the way" and hung up. We called back again because that was a rude way of handling a customer and received the same response back in the same manner at which point we requested a full refund.  We understand these are hard times and things will happen like getting backed up or a misestimation of the time it will take to deliver (we are only a few blocks away). That said, just be upfront with your paying customers and don't be rude or dismissive, as that's what will make me take my business elsewhere. I hope Square on Square improves in this area as they had something great going in terms of food and following.

We order delivery thru DoorDash. Was expecting a jumbo shrimp with jumbo shrimp. First of all we receive little baby shrimps that we're gowy and the lobster soup was a discussing soup that had NO taste! It was a really bad decision to order from this restaurant. We also order wonton soup and it was horrible they came more than six but the taste was horrible. Plus the price for this is extremely wrong, not even worth it!!! Bad bad bad!
Online ordered the lunch pork fried rice during COVID. I was only able to finish half and will save the rest for left overs :) being Chinese, this is definitely delicious in my book!

This is a clear front runner for worst Chinese in center city. We only ordered because my wife lost track of which are the good options (Golden Lake, New South China, Mandarin Palace, etc.). This one was 30 minutes late, forgot the sweet and sour sauce, and neglected to cook the broccoli. The food was bland, but they get one extra star for the pork fried rice, which is legitimately good. Everything else was trash. 

Karen - I don't know if you read Yelp reviews, but please don't order from here anymore. Thx.

Ordered delivery through Grub Hub. Restaurant delivers so no tracking. Food an hour and a half late and Restaurant will not pick up phone. Trying to support small business during a pandemic. Be honest, pick up the phone and work it out. Instead - no show and I am caller 658 on grub hub to get my money back. Done with Grub Hub and Square on Square. Lousy business behavior has nothing to do with a pandemic.

They make great food but they poorly handled my complaint of metal in my stir fry. I called to alert them of metal shards in my food, to which the man who answered, reasoned it was normal for little metal pieces to come off the equipment they use in very hot stir fries. I guess we just have different standards for food.
Happy the excellent service is back! Friendly service, hot and great food! ...the General Tso Chicken is the same as on Chestnut Street too!

I am completely horrified after finding a COCKROACH in my takeout lunch order today. Square on Square did refund my meal, but it does not make up for this extreme violation of health code. I am not being over dramatic, if you wish to see more evidence, please go to https://www.phila.gov/services/permits-violations-licenses/get-a-license/business-licenses-permits-and-approvals/food-businesses/look-up-a-food-safety-inspection-report/ and look up Square on Square to see other violations. I will never be ordering from Square on Square again.

I had the chicken with eggplant and it was delicious. I could tell the ingredients were fresh. It had the perfect amount of heat. I think this is the best Chinese option in an area pretty thin on good Chinese food. I would highly recommend.

This has been our go to Chinese place for years. It has pretty standard dishes and they recently relocated. The place is smaller than the first one, however the food hasn't change much and we are not complaining. They do make their food without the Ajinomoto on request and have a homemade chili sauce which always hits the spot on a cold rainy day. 
Much better than the average Chinese take out places!

We took about a year hiatus from these guys after some disappointing meals.  
Ordered via uber delivery to give it another go. Food was delivered quickly and still warm.
Ordered CFR, CLM, dumplings, pepper steak and wonton soup.  Both the CFR and CLM tasted like burnt oil and a cross between an old frying pan and cleaning solution.  Just awful. Tossed it out. Horrible. The pepper steak was soggy and had the same taste. Looked like tripe after being left out for days. Threw out the entire $70 order. Never again.

So I went a bit nuts and ordered $40 worth of Chinese food for just myself last night but this spot has some good things going on inside.

Establishment is very cleanly, food is fresh tasting, and if you check in Wed or Sun during 5pm-7pm I believe there running a speical you get a free glass of wine.

I ordered the General Tso's order and chose spicy level. The taste of the chicken definitely had ginger in it and is a little bit different from most other restaurants General Tso's. If I order again would upgrade to very spicy as the chicken had a kick but not as spicy as I had envisoned. 

The eggplant and beef was the star of the night. Very Good! Now I do own a mug that says give me eggplant or death, that is how passionate I am with my eggplant. It really is quite perfect.

Spring rolls were on target and I would order again, spare ribs needed more sauce in my opinion. I would like to mention I put a note in my take out order for packets of hot sauce and duck sauce and the owner went above and beyond by mixing a special hot sauce that was AMAZING! Also, adding duck sauce in a container, it really is the small things that make the experience that much better! I plan on coming back to try more of there items but as I said at the start of the review I have a lot of leftovers with $40 worth of Chinese for one person!
So glad we found this place. Great Chinese food in a great location in Rittenhouse Sq.

business.name: Sang Kee Noodle House

attributes.Ambience: {'touristy': False, 'hipster': False, 'romantic': False, 'divey': False, 'intimate': False, 'trendy': False, 'upscale': False, 'classy': True, 'casual': True}

business.categories: Restaurants, Ethnic Food, Noodles, Food, Dim Sum, Specialty Food, Chinese

reviews.text:
Absolutely terrible quality of food. I've been here a couple of times per covid and it was fine and not sure what happened but it's absolutely a place to avoid now. We got 5 dishes the wait took a long time, the quality was so bad and the portion size was so small compared to the price that we paid. For reference I am Cantonese and know what these dishes taste like if they were made properly. 

The first was the pineapple fried rice and it was so sad. They used canned pineapples but they didn't even look diced like they straight up poured it out the can, strained it, and threw it in fried rice. It didn't come in a pineapple (which I supposed makes sense if they don't use real pineapple but comon the picture had a pineapple isn't it false advertising at this point). The flavor was also really unimpressive. 

The garlic pea leaves we got were supposed to be stir fried but they BOILED it. There was no flavor at all. I can't believe they boiled it.. either they are super short staffed in the kitchen or they absolutely don't care anymore. Nothing on the pictures look like that came on the table. 

The Dan Dan noodle portion was so small. The flavor was okay but overall not good and wouldn't get again. 

The dry pot chicken was also sad. The coating And the chicken didn't mix well at all. And the texture was all wrong. I'm not sure how they messed this up but they really did. It was also really really salty. 

The chongqin noodles were okay. Not a super huge fan but the portion size was also really small. 

Over all we paid over 80 dollars and not everyone was full there was 4 of us. What and epic waste of time, money, and rental space. Honestly I am so upset I don't think I will ever come back this experience was absolutely abysmal.
Very good ramen & duck. But a veggie dish included little tofu and dry noodles. It seems items are inconsistent.

Great food for the price!

The shrimp rolls were packed with shrimp - we were shocked at how full they were.

The Dan Dan noodles were just okay. I probably wouldn't order those again. 

The chicken with broccoli was good. Classic/traditional taste. 

We will definitely keep Sang Kee Noodle House in mind for a rainy day lazy meal.
Love this place, I have no ideas why the reviews are mediocre. I've been coming here for lunch for ages.
Great food and very cheap for how good the food is. We had green beans, pork belly, fried spicy chicken, and boiled fish. Every part was delicious!
The food was delicious but the service wasn't so good. Had keep on calling the server over when we wanted something. I would go to this only for takeout only .

Honestly, Sang Kee is a great spot to grab a meal. I used to take my mother out to eat here all the time when I was in Philly. 

If you enjoy pad thai, they have a great one. Also, a great thai iced tea. 

It's an enjoyable dine-in spot! Great service and ambience. I have had take-out from here, but this is a nice place to sit and enjoy your meal.
Great noodle soup I never had.   Peking duck good.        Sautéed Snow pea leaves  tasty

I had the shrimp wonton soup serve in a bowl. It was good, but in my opinion, it was overpowering with sauce to the point that my mouth had a very salty aftertaste. I had also had the steamed shanghai buns, the texture was a bit clumpy and not the texture you crave in soft serve. They have a lit of other Chinese sweets and hot meals as well, but I probably won't go out of my way to come back here.

This was an absolutely delicious and authentic Chinese meal. (Tasted just like my house mates used to make :) )

I had the lamb ramen and the braised sweet pea greens.

The dishes were packed full of flavour, in a rich broth

I will definitely eat here again, and recommend it.

The sweet pea greens were $18 though, so I didn't think they were worth the price- though they were delicious.
Very nice restaurant. Good Chinese food and my always go-to restaurant during covid time. Food is fast and nice packaged and delivered.
This is the best Chinese food hands down in university city! The General Tao's chicken is heavenly and I would eat it every day if I could!! Portions are huge and definitely worth the price!

Nice and Simple spot 
Food was definitely  Delicious and enjoyable
Great if your looking to have a nice quiet lunch

Their Chinese New Years menus is highly superior to all other menus. Everything is delicious and cooked to perfection. The lamb chops and chicken bowl is mouthwatering to the max. The meat was like velvet and the steamed fish was beautiful and cooked to perfection. Really great meal, and we haven't even got to dessert yet!!!  Best meal!! I would give this meal6 (6)  ****** six stars !!! Best Chinese New Years meal I ever had in years!!  The braised pork shoulder was juicy and succulent cooked to a turn. The eight precious pudding was excellent as was the rest of the meal.

Nowhere near as good as the other Sang Kee duck house in chinatown. Oh and they completely left out the most important item in my order - the duck - and I had to get a partial refund since they had closed.

Honestly even the food that I did get wasn't close to the level of flavor that Sang Kee Duck house has - highly recommend that one! not here

Placed order on Grubhub and the food said it was prepared and then it changed to say it was being delivered soon. Nothing ever came and the restaurant didn't answer the phone after 7 attempts.  Piss poor service
My favorite restaurant! Their chow fun is amazing.  I live in NYC now but I dream of Sang Kee on a daily basis.

This is my go-to spot when my family visits Philly. I really like the service here. We have a booth that we sit at every time and the hosts always allow us to request where we want to sit. The kitchen is also pretty fast and most of your dishes will come out all at once. 

My favorite dish is the Boiled Flounder Fillet in Szechuan Hot Oil. It's looks super red but is actually not that spicy. The chilly oil adds a nice zing to the flavor and the flounder is always cooked to perfection and falls apart in your mouth. There's also cabbage and silky tofu in the soup. 

My second favorite is the Sautéed String Beans. They come with this really tasty minced pork. It's honestly the best string beans dish I've every had. They're sautéed to perfection with the right balance between soft and crispy. 

Other standout dishes include: Golden Jumbo Shrimp with Honey Walnut, Sautéed Snow Pea Leaves, and Fish Fillet Congee. Their congee is honestly really really good and authentic.
I love their food ! It was so good. I highly recommend the shrimp wonton soup it is amazing !! Best I have ever had

I can recommend the Thai iced tea, and the beef chow fun. Are used to go to this place all the time when I used to live near and it was really good.

I ordered delivery the other day, but the roast duck really is not good. The skin isn't crispy, and my order was mostly bones and only dark meat. The picture leaves a lot to be desired for the price.

We ate here on consecutive nights. Night #1 was spectacular, with good mai tais, delicious chicken bites and shrimp wontons, excellent roast duck and udon and pork belly. A complete delight including the charming service. Night #2 the drinks were even better yet the food was a bit less  delicious. Tomato/tofu/beef and bulgogi entrees were.....fine. Service was once again charming in spite of the obstacles restaurants are facing not being able to operate inside their own spaces.
Chicken pad thai was really good. Service during covid with takeout was great. A little overpriced but well worth it.  Inside Sheraton hotel. Recommend for sure.
the lo mein wasn't even lo mein noodles. the noodles are thin and very very dry and flavorless. the portion is great but not what was expected at all.

Terrible service with okay food, not a recipe for success. We were the only customers in the entire place and it took an hour to get our food, unacceptable. The main guy continually said the food would come out soon to no avail. I would not recommend this place unless you want to waste lots of time to eat mediocre food.

Came here for the second time and it wows me every single time! Even thought it was on the night of Chinese New Year, my friends and I only waited for 5-10 minutes, which was not bad at all! The food was always pleasant and not a long wait for the food to come as well. It's really nice to have a decent Chinese restaurant on my college campus when I'm craving for authentic Chinese cuisine. We had a difficulty splitting the bill but the staff and boss were very patient with us and resolved it neatly in the end. They even offer us a Chinese red packet/envelopewith a Sang Kee coupon in it to celebrate Chinese New Year. I was so impressed and it's really good advertising strategy for customers to come back as well. I am 100% coming back Sang Kee!

business.name: Ocean Harbor

reviews.text:
Dim sum dim sum dim sum.... repeat after me.. dim sum! I never thought I'll be so glad to find this restaurant when I realize that it will be a struggle to find standard Cantonese style dim-sum in Chinatown of Philadelphia. I think everyone else is gravitating toward the northern style or soup dumplings. I always see a line across the street from this. I found out about this restaurant from a friend, who said that all Chinese locals would specifically visit this restaurant if you're in Center city and want dim sum. 

Walking into this restaurant you would have to walk up stairs, and when you get to the banquet hall, which is on the top of the stairs. You would have to flag a waiter to say how many people are in your party. Then you would have to let the waiter staff know what tea you want to have, as they then leave you with an order card. 

You then wait for pushcarts of dim sum being brought around by female staff, or in my experience, since I have sat at tables on the event stage - flag the dim sum lady to get a various dim sum that I love. The lady will then punch on your card for it being a small, medium, large of extra special dish. Then you start to eat and all is good.

I have been wanting to try this place the last few times I visited so I was happy to get a chance this time but wish I didn't. The dim sum is subpar and overpriced. One of the ladies pushing the cart kept coming over every 3 minutes to push you to order something off her cart eventhough you told her THREE times we are fine and we would like to wait until we finish first. Only one waiter working that never comes by after he takes your tea order. You have to pay at the desk so when I went up to pay, the cashier/owner noticed i was in front of her but was too busy signing a delivery invoice and made me wait another two minutes before she took my credit card/bill. The credit card machine only gives you the option to tip 18% or more, What?!? She never said a word throughout the whole transaction, not even a thank you, she had a "i want to kill you" stare the whole time. For just a moment there I had the urge to stick my hand through the little opening and grab her by the shirt and say "What's your problem"?!

Stopped in for some  Dim Sum after finding my favorite place across the street was closed.

They have a pretty go0d selection to choose from but a major complaint is they did not move the carts around to frequently, and a lot of the food was not very hot and had to be reheated in the kitchen,

It was super weird when we stopped by on a Saturday evening and were the only customers the entire time. The place looks like it could hold quite a crowd, and the food was great! However, it was a little hard to get to due to some nearby roads being closed for events downtown, so perhaps that was the cause for the slow evening. Nonetheless, we really enjoyed our time, for starters, the soups were absolutely delicious! Won ton, sweet'n'sour, and egg drop - YUM!!! Would totally go back just for those!

We also had the half peking duck and an assortment of dim sum plates. Tbh, the dim sum wasn't all that amazing and I wouldn't get it again, but the duck was great, and there were plenty of other menu options I'd like to go back to try.
Classic dishes made in old fashioned way. Knowledgeable wait staff. Huge space for parties big and small.  Fresh vegetables with nice cuts of meat and seafood

Ocean Harbor is my go to Cantonese dim sum place in Philly. There really aren't many options if you're looking for the authentic cart-pushing dim sum experience and Ocean Harbor is your best bet. And it's even better if you have a Chinese speaking friend with you because the weekend process to get a table here during the house of 11am-12pm is pure and utter chaos when it's busy. They use to have a number system but now it's just a wait in line process on their stairs (people cram in there, masks are required, but just be wary if that's not your cup of tea - see what I did there) and you must be patient else it's all that more overwhelming. They will also escort you often to a table that hasn't been completely cleared and is dirty--but that's just part of their system--someone will come around shortly to clean it, but they like you standing awkwardly there so it's now "reserved". I don't necessarily understand their methods or the madness but the food is yummy and it's worth it. Dim sum is always pretty good and the pan fried beef noodles are my fave. If you're craving something interesting off and part of the secret menu -- order Ying Yang rice. It's fried rice with half topped with a white shrimp sauce and the other half topped with a ketchupy pork sauce. It's awesome and a must try if you're feeling adventurous. Also, on my comment about how it's easier to eat here when you have a Chinese speaking friend? Hit me up I'm always happy to help and eat dim sum. Enjoy!

How I like my dim sum - pushed around on carts and steaming in their perfectly sized tins.

Only got a few pictures of the actual dishes--everything is pretty standard for dim sum.

If you have a particular dim sum dish in mind that you want and don't see it, you're even allowed to ask for it and they may make a few fresh batches if it's possible!

The staff are actually really kind despite the line that usually forms to get inside. I came here Saturday at noon and the wait wasn't long at all. 

Everyone here can speak Chinese/English for the most part. Thank goodness for this ABC who speaks Chinglish! Strangely enough I only know the Chinese names of some of these dishes.

Arrived an hour before they close and we had the restaurant all to ourselves! Upon arrival and being seated, the table was already seat up and tea was provided. I believe it was jasmine tea. The waitress was patient and allowed us to take our time looking at the menu. The food portions were huge for the entrees/dishes and the services was good. I would come back here and I recommend this place to others.

Not sure why Ocean Harbor is rated so low because I think this is pretty much the best dim sum places in the city!! The food is always cooked perfectly with so much flavor. Traditional dim sum does not get much better than this. Have not returned to dine in since covid, but my boyfriend and I have ordered takeout and eaten it in the car on multiple occasions while our food was still hot. The servers are also always nice enough to put extra chili oil in our bags. Excited to come back soon and have the full dim sum experience again!

We came Sunday morning and could only find 1-hr parking so we were a bit worried, but we were in and out of ocean harbor in ~40 minutes. The restaurant was packed but as soon as we got there the waiter signaled to us and we were seated immediately in the corner. I've missed cart style dim sum, so I was really happy to find this place. It's so fast and it's hard to resist with so many options right in front of you! Since we were in the corner, some carts missed us but most of the wait staff still stopped by, so no big deal! The food was delicious, and I'm super picky about my cheung fun but I enjoyed theirs! Definitely recommend stopping by for quick service and for traditional, yummy cart style dim sum!

More than just dim sum. Their hot and sour soup might be my favorite in the city. The ma po tofu is rich and flavorful and just the right amount of spicy for my tastes. Chinese broccoli is always a favorite. 

We've tried pork lo mein, and it was good. Pork shu mai were also tasty. Takeout portions are generous. My orders fed me for days. 

Inside there are round banquet tables with linens, space between tables so dim sum carts can maneuver. If you're a fan of dim sum, it looks like most other dim sum places.

All around good value and taste.
Came here on a sat. after 12pm. Food was subpar, nothing special. Food were being left out on tables getting cold instead of being offered around the resturant. Carts were on standby in the middle.

Is there really a good dim sum place in Philly? Besides this location, Ocean City by Sangkee is worse. Of course service is terrible. Always super crowded on weekends. Takes forever to a table and then iced water or a refill for it. But guess what? It's where I go for dim sum in Chinatown. Dim sum tastes good, comes out hot and fresh, and is a much cleaner place compared to Ocean City. However, if you can venture out into South Philly, I recommend Wokano. It's way better and is my favorite spot for dim sum in the city.

One of my favorite dim sum places of all time! Totally forgot to review it only because I'm so used to just coming here on a Saturday with friends that even after leaving this city, I crave it when I'm here.


It's so very loud in the best way. Lots of round tables and bustling carts with the best siomai, buns, turnip cake and delicious dough fried sticks splashed with soy sauce. If you love Chinese broccoli or pork and shrimp stuffed dumplings, this is for you. It's so simple and good and you could get stuffed for under $20 with some tea. It's so homey and one of the nicest places to relax in an authentic restaurant that doesn't overprice its food or try to be fancy.

Love the Dim Sum here.  It is loud, like a typical Hong Kong style tea house.  It has the roller carts, and you choose the food as they come along.  Food is delicious and authentic.  AWESOME!!!  Highly recommend, and I think it is better than the Dim sum in Southern California!

we love it！
推荐蛋挞 凤爪 排骨 一定要吃！！！
尤其是蛋挞 小小的 但是很酥很嫩 吃一个会意犹未尽的
烧麦 虾饺 叉烧包 牛百叶也还不错
不推荐肠粉 比较厚
非常不推荐芋头酥 很油很干很噎没调味！

Been to Ocean Harbor throughout the years with my family and sometimes with friends. The only time the staff treated us kindly was when I went with my dad because he knows the waiter and dimsum aunties. Today when I was there with my bf and friend, which both doesn't eat pork... so I needed to double check if it contains pork in the food. One of the auntie rudely responded screaming " WHY WOULD THERE BE PORK IF IT'S SHRIMP BALLS?" As some of you would know... just because the title is shrimp balls.. doesn't necessarily means that there's only shrimp in it. Most of the times, in Chinese cooking there are pork mixed into almost everything. Not that this review would change any of their attitudes there, but if you are thinking about eating there... just be aware that you may encounter some attitudes from the aunties and waiter.

Chaotic and busy but good food, just like the kind you'd get in Hong Kong. We came at 2 pm and the restaurant was filled but it got emptier by 3. The staff were accommodating and service was very quick (because you choose food off of the rolling carts)

Carts galore. Good food. Fried dough on point. Egg tarts are smaller but crispy, which is the kind I like. You know it's legit when the cart servers are a little rude. Not on purpose of course, cultural differences. Will come again.

Great Dim Sum place with a fairly wide selection. Super in and out, so if you're in a rush or looking for a quick meal this place is perfect. Not everything was super hot and the tofu was not the best but everything else was great.

So my reference point is from visiting chinatowns all over the USA including NY Chicago Houston San Fran Boston Seattle. Philly chinatown is missing Dim Sum even though a lot of restaurants put that in the name. Ocean Harbor is actually a dim sum restaurant cantonese style including the standard siu mai and ha gow and churng fun and spare ribs etc...They serve via traditional carts coming around. The atmosphere is loud and spacious just like how it should be. This is the standard for dim sum places and if you're a visitor you should check this out if looking for Cantonese Dim Sum.

Delicious dim sum restaurant in Philadelphia. Went with friends who guided me through the foods. If you don't see one of your favorite dishes, just ask the servers with the carts and they'll bring it for you. My favorite was the schrimp dumplings. Tried e chicken feet, but wasn't a fan.

This was the best tasting dim sum I've had In awhile.  Their siomai, harkow, pork spare ribs, beef dumplings and taro dumplings were all fantastic.  Normally, some dishes are good and some bad and some not so bad.  Everything I tried was tasty and flavorful.  Definitely recommended.

Other than Ocean City, Ocean Harbor is another go-to place for Cantonese DIm Sum dishes on traditional carts. Arrived at around 12:30 pm and the place was packed. There appeared to be no systemic seat arrangement in place so we had to line up and wait. Luckily the line moved rather quickly and in about 20 minutes we were seated. Expect extremely confined seating place and loud noises.

Ordered mostly dim sum dishes and will be comparing some of them against Ocean City. 

Ha Gau (shrimp dumplings): wrap was too thick and too much starch in the stuffing. 

Shiu Mai: tasted standard.

Chicken feet: standard. 

Beef tripes: a bit bland.

Beef meatballs: unlike Ocean City, they placed Yuba at the bottom, and added Worcestershire sauce on my request. The taste was far greater. 

Egg tarts: small but tasty, puff pastry kept its dry texture, and the egg yolk stuffing was not too sweet.

String beans: stir-fried with dices of pork and pork fat, a great veggie addition to dim sums.

Congee with preserved eggs and pork: did not add pepper as Ocean City did, kept the rice taste of standard congee, but a bit bland due to minimal amount of preserved eggs and seasoning. 

Steamed rice rolls with shrimp: standard.

Steamed rice rolls with twice-fried dough sticks（炸两）: a pleasant surprise caught by us when it was carried out by a staff member. The plate went empty rather quickly. The rice rolls was freshly made and dough sticks very crispy, will recommend this over the rice rolls with shrimp.

Roasted duck: ordered via staff. Roasting technique was quite nice. Crispy skin, melting fat, sweet and savory taste, and a lot of duck meat. 

Overall: don't mind the rather chaotic environment, just enjoy the food!

The dim sum is decent and I think it's the best in the area. It's the traditional push carts that go around each table. The chicken feet, shrimp dumpling, wonton dumpling, pork ribs and thin rice noodle layered with shrimp are my go too.

business.name: Wokano

reviews.text:
So sad this place has only 3 stars! Not going to lie it made me alittle worried too when I went. It was a Monday morning so not a lot of carts were out but I wanted to get dim sum when I got off my plane that morning. 
I walk in and ordered some tea. I immediately get brought the dumpling cart. There I ordered a bunch of dumplings and buns that I liked.

Within mins I was full from delicious dim sum. I do recommend parking a few streets over and walking over. The parking lot is small and has a ton of traffic. Shrimp crepes and shrimp crystal dumplings are my favorite. These were cooked to perfection! Def. Would love to come back here again.

Dim sum for breakfast? Dim sum for brunch? You better believe it.

Wokano is one of my favorite places to get weekend morning dim sum. It's simple, comforting, affordable, and relaxing. It's everything I want in a first-meal of the day. 

If you go a little later in the day or the evening, it fills up quickly. But going in the morning ensures there's likely a table free for you to walk right in and grab. 

There's a very friendly man who walks around making sure you have water, I think he might be the manager or the owner. He's always happy to see returning customers and greets us warmly each time. 

When I go to most places to eat, I like to try something different each time. But I find myself always going for the same items at Wokano. But no matter what you get, make sure to at least get the sesame buns and egg custard buns, and a pot of tea. You can not go wrong with these as part of your order!

It's filling, it's delicious, and it's easy on the wallet. 

I also love that when you sit down, you can eat relatively quickly: people are walking carts around the dining area with the food ready to go for you to select and enjoy. 

My only issue is that, unless you live nearby and can walk there, I recommend you take a cab or rideshare. The shopping center parking lot is mayhem. It's packed with a food market and other stores in a small condensed area, so navigating your car in that parking lot is an endurance challenge. Save yourself the trouble and enjoy an Uber or a walk. 

If you want a nice AM meal, or if you need to work off the hangover from last night, you will surely feel better after visiting Wokano!

Stopped by for Cantonese-style dim sum, my friends and I were early here. Service was pretty quick, there is a number of staple dim sum dishes, that is appreciated. Not really much complaints, Wokano reminded me of a dim sum place I tried where the owners or workers are trying. There was one dish my friend ordered that she couldn't eat. The place is frequented by local Asians with cars, as there is a parking lot. 

Outside the parking situation was very interesting. Parking attendees were very snappy, you had to designate for being restaurant or supermarket. Cannot do both. 

May come again, if friend decides to drive. But probably not.
Service is lacking but food is pretty good. I didn't like their chicken feet though. Their Chinese broccoli with garlic was surprisingly good and flavorful

Came here for dim sum around 12PM. They took my temperature and it was 85 degrees and said it was too high and they couldn't serve me? Last time I checked the average body temperature is around 98 degrees. What a joke.

Went to a different restaurant, had my temperature checked and my temperature was normal.

First time here! Usually, I check Yelp before visiting a joint. If I saw there's only 3 stars, I will most likely not eat there. Howeverrrrr, we came. We ate. We left very satisfied!

Came around 1:30-2pm. Super dead, they check temperature & hand sanitizer is provided then we got seated.
We ordered turnip cake, stuffed fried tofu, shrimp dumplings, sticky rice, beef tripe, bean curd skin roll, golden egg bun, pork shu mai, fried shrimp pork dumplings, shrimp rice noodle, and oolong tea.
Yes, I know. We over ordered. I always do. It's okayyy, I love leftovers lol.

I wish tea pot had a strainer cause I don't really like tea leafs in my cup, but whatevs. The food thooo, it was fast fresh and good!! Like, EVERY. SINGLE. ITEM. WAS. GOOD!! My most fave was the fried shrimp pork dumplings. It's the ones that are shaped like a football. Never had it before & it was delishhh!

Service was good. Typical fast, straight forward Chinese/dim sum service yaknow.

Definitely worth a visit! 10/10 would rec :)
Don't do it. Dim sum ridiculous imposter. Picked up $70 order last week. Sorry I drove up from Wilmington and wasted time money and last entry to Philly for a while.

A nice substitute to your normal dim sum in Chinatown. More spacious but depending on what day you come, parking could be a nightmare. Food is also hit or miss. Some places come out steaming hot, others are ice cold.
Really really good Sunday dim sum. We were visiting and keep walking by so we decided to try you will not be disappointed quick service. Delicious and tasty!
Grew up eating dim sum and they definitely have all the traditional dishes. Beyond that the staff is always so kind to my kids. Fast and parking on site. We go often.

Since my last review, I've come back a couple of times and it's been getting worse and worse. They never come around with the carts, even when its Sunday prime time. They're always out of the MAIN dimsum stuff and you always have to order it from the kitchen, which either they forget about or they end up taking SUPER long to get to you. The only thing I'd say is still okay are their portion sizes/prices for their dimsum. However, I probably won't be returning for a while to this dimsum place because of the lack of service and availability of dimsum dishes.

Edit: went there today for dinner, and the soup was cold and we had to ask them to heat it up again. We had $60 worth of food in the original bill that was given to us, +18% tip would have been $71. but when the server came back for us to sign the credit card receipt it became $65. An additional $5 extra was added in our bill so we ended up subtracting $5 off the tip. Make sure you double check the bill after they ring it.

Good food, fast service, and good price value. The pork bun or steam bun is not as big in size that I would like but its okay. I definitely would come back and recommend to friends.

Do not go here. My son went there last month  and his whole family got food poisoning. I went there today and it feels like someone shot me in the stomach. I have gotten food poisoning before but this is one of the worst that I can remember. It is 1 am and I cannot sleep my stomach holiest so bad. The waiters can't speak English and their service is horrible. If I can give this restaurant negative stars I would.

4 - for food, 4 for ambience, 3 for variety of carts

Setting: Walked in with the two of us on a Sunday 11AM lunch time. We were able to be seated promptly. 

Ambience: Bright, not overly crowded, much more quiet compared to Ocean Harbor, the staff were not rude and yelling at us, we did not feel rushed

Service: The carts came around regularly, but there was a general lull after about an hour. 

Food:
Chicken feet - pretty classic

Pork spare ribs - we actually got two orders of this, they were rich in flavor, well salted/spiced

Sticky rice - a little on the salty side

Pork shumai - standard

Crispy shrimp balls - probably the best thing on the carts, they are light, crispy, jam-packed with flavor - must have!! and not seen at Ocean Harbor

Congee - nice depth of flavor, filling

Tips/Takeaways:
-Must get the crispy shrimp balls
-Free Parking
-Credit cards accepted
-Quieter and less of a rude atmosphere compared to Ocean Harbor
-Would recommend for your Dim Sum cravings regularly, recommend every 3-6 months

I have to say the experience was saltier than their salty fried rice. 
I have eaten with family and friends before and sometimes order take out from this restaurant. It is clear that over time the quality has deteriorated more and more. I will no longer be visiting this restaurant ever again.
I got takeout for 2 orders of the Salty Fish Fried Rice. Not only was there no actual fish in the salty FISH fried rice, the restaurant replaced it with tiny, cheap, dried shrimp. The rice also tasted burnt and looked brown/gray. The food looked like it had been reheated several times and burnt (see photos). The quality of the food is disastrous and the food was inedible. 
I would also add that when I came to pick up the order, no one was present at the cash register and I had to wait a while to pick up my order.

Tony the owner are the best and friendly
My like the food the price are ok 
Great food and dim sums are the best 
We have couple birthday and party a few times there. 
Thank you Tony 
Keep a great work with your crews.

Tony the owner are the best and friendly
My like the food the price are ok 
Great food and dim sums are the best 
We have couple birthday and party a few times there. lot of dim sums starting at 10 o'clock.
Thank you Tony 
Keep a great work with your crews.

Worst service ever the food was gross oily and dirty. I would not come here again it is just simply disgusting. The teacup have oil and lipstick stains.some of the theme song taste like overnight and microwave food.

Tony the owner are the best and friendly
My like the food the price are ok 
Great food and dim sums are the best 
We have couple birthday and party a few times there. 
Thank you Tony 
Keep a great work with your crews.

If u are looking for a dim sum place that has free parking and is not located in Chinatown, then this place is for u!  This is more like your normal chinese established restaurant. It's not your normal take out. We got dim sum which is only served during the mornings through 3pm. When u first walk in, u are greeted by a waiting staff and is given menus and tea. Right after we are seated with our stuff, immediately comes a cart full of delicious food waiting to be eaten up by 3 hungry men. Like a beast waiting for its prey to come out. We ordered a bunch of things including chicken fingers, the two popular dumplings, and many more delicious food. Now their service.... it needs some adjustments. Whenever you say thank you, they dont say your welcome. They just walk away. It's kinda like saying "yeah yeah give me my money and leave". Me being Asian, I expected this kind of service, but it's something about these kinds of restaurants that gives me an unwelcoming sense. But they did give us our food on time and we was taken care of. It's just their manners that need adjustments. Overall rating: 4/5

Friday night devours turned into a full deep sea swim! I visited Wokano Restaurant for dinner. While being here i order the fish fillet in black bean sauce . It came in full force full of flavor and full of spices. This spot is amazing  make sure y'all pull Up they're open till 12:00am. #chinesefood #chinese #food #philadelphia #philly #fish #foodporn #foodphotography #foodgasm #foodie #latenight #latenightdinner
Decent dim sum spot, the prices are reasonable but best of all there is a parking lot! Otherwise does not stand out, it is what you would expect from dim sum.

Wokano is a great place to come if you're looking to escape the craziness of dim sum in Chinatown. The food is decent and it's not that hard to get a table. Their menu is pretty extensive and it has the authentic feel with the carts being pushed around. I will warn that the parking lot in the plaza is pretty horrific and will definitely leave you feeling stressed and overwhelmed. 

Pro tip: walk or Uber to avoid Parking or just park in the surrounding neighborhoods, order a noodle or two from the menu and then just grab siu mai and other foods from the carts

If ordering by phone, be sure to ask for the price! I ordered a roast pork wonton noodle soup and lo mein from the menu that's linked via this Yelp page (total around $15). I showed up and was told my total was $21.50. I told the cashier/waiter that their website stated different prices but was told that they don't have a website. I showed him the website on my phone with their address and logo but he was insistent that someone else must have made it.. and didn't offer to try to fix the false advertising problem. Food was okay but was prepared quick.

My family and I were craving some dim sum, and decided to try Wokano out in South Philly. Arriving at the restaurant, there is a huge Vietnamese plaza in the area, and the parking lot was packed full. We managed to squeeze into a space, and entered the restaurant. The ambiance was that of a traditional dim sum restaurant with the metal carts and round tables. It's not the most ornate designs I've seen, but definitely still has the ambiance of a dim sum restaurant.

Note: the waiters and waitresses here speak Mandarin, for the most part. We tried several dim sum, including shu Mai, Cheung fun, and soon juk goon. What was a bit disappointing was the service of the carts, as they were not moving around as frequently as we would have liked, rather they stood around the same area. Additionally, some of the dim sum wasn't really hot and fresh, rather feeling lukewarm and as if it had sat there for a bit. The shu mai was pretty okay, and the Cheung fun was a highlight, but everything else dim sum was decent. We also ordered beef chow fun and ban lam bo (stone fish pot), and both of those were very delicious. The chow fun was made with the right amount of gravy sauce, and the fish was so crispy. Overall, I would recommend coming here for dinner, but you can find better dim sum elsewhere.

business.name: China Gourmet

business.categories: Restaurants, Chinese, Cantonese, Dim Sum

reviews.text: Came here for lunch around 12:30 because we were craving some dim sum and didn't feel like looking for parking in Chinatown. The place is not in a great area and the floors inside were pretty slippery without any caution signs to let us know. We were seated right away for a party of three and had to wait around 10 minutes for any carts to come by us. However, once we got our food, we were pretty satisfied with everything. This place has all of the classic dim sum dishes and hit the spot. Also keep in mind they will charge you for whatever tea you order. Despite that, I'll probably come back again in the future.

If I could give a 0 star I would. Came in for dim sum and food was already not as good as before. Went to pay for my bill and the hostess accuses my table of getting a noodle dish. She even had the nerve to come to my table and check the plates to see if there was a noodle dish. How unprofessional and rude! Will never come back and I suggest everyone check what they're paying for because I would not be surprised if they just add additional items to your ticket.

Had a craving for dim sum and had heard that China Gourmet was good and we weren't disappointed!

The dim sum was as good as we've gotten in Chinatown.  We went with six people so we got a wide assortment of dishes and they were all good... dumpling, turnip cakes, tripe, chicken feet, sticky rice.  We especially liked the sweet bakes pork buns... my kids asked for more when the carts came back around.  

We'll definitely be back again when we crave some dim sum!

Came in for brunch to have dim sum. Place is huge, plenty of parking, waitress and waiters wore mask. We did the traditional push cart picking and got some dumplings, chicken feet, white crepes with soy sauce, taro cakes, buns, fried buns, fried taro balls, intestines mixed with tenders. 

I was waiting on other dishes like big crab/shrimp balls and chow fun but it didn't come out. I think we could have ordered it but we didn't bother. We also came in just as they were opened, as we were leaving I saw other dishes coming out.

Overall it's ok.
Close to authentic. Good not great. Service was attentive. I don't know if I would return.

If you have your wedding here for a traditional Asian wedding, you will not regret it. Their photo booth and photographer was amazing! Photoshop both were such great quality and they captured all the right moments and sent photos the next day which was very surprising. The staff worked quick and diligently and listened to what we wanted . Food was good and decor was very nice as well.
Just went today and everything I had was much better than my previous trip. Flavor wise it was a lot tastier and overall pretty satisfying.

This place is convenient for people who don't want to drive to Chinatown and located next to a Chinese supermarket. However, a few times I've been here there have been huge issues with their sanitation standards and the service is atrocious. Most servers are okay, but one lady in particular, a tall middle age lady with black hair and a stank face always says the most nasty things and gives a horrible attitude totally unprovoked. I live near Chinatown so I don't come here very often but of the few times that I have, this has really stood out to me. Enough to the point that it prompted me to write this review. I've never in my Yelp history given such low ratings but just because they are busy doesn't mean they can treat people like crap. 

I came here and it was 10% full. It was my dads birthday, a big occasion and after a tumultuous few years regarding his health we decided to have our close family come out to a small dinner to celebrate. We asked for a small private room in the back so the kids could have their space. She said we "wouldn't spend enough money to get the room" I've been in the private rooms many times and have never heard of a minimum. The manager told her to bring us to the room and she refused. Not trying to argue with this lady we all left to the restaurant down the street and my dad is heated by the way we were just treated. Mind you, we never have a budget with food when celebrating special occasions. Regardless, we didn't have to explain ourselves to this lady let alone meet these made up requirements. 

This is the same lady that told a family member that she "shouldn't have worn flip flops" when she slipped and fell on their wet bathroom floor and also the same lady that brought us our check and asked if we were ready to leave as soon as our food arrived last time and the time before that. We have a family of about 45 people. None of us want to return here despite the convenient location. We've all been offended by her in our experiences. Nobody deserves to be talked to this way and I hope this business starts seeing the consequences of the horrible attitude of this particular server.
They have the best dim sum in Philadelphia.  Even though there are dim sum restaurants much closer, we are willing to drive from Delaware County for our dim sum.

We've been getting dim sum takeout from China Gourmet for quite some now. Even though China Gourmet is in Northeast Philly, and a lot further than Chinatown's Ocean Harbor and Ocean City, it is worth the 50 minutes roundtrip drive. 

We've never eaten inside the restaurant, as it's just my husband and I, and we've gotten used to getting dim sum to go since the pandemic started. Also, I can't imagine how long the wait time can be during peak dim sum hour. 

Anyway, The variety and quality of the dim sum dishes here are just so much better. And the fact that I have not gotten food poisoning from here gets an extra star from me. Yay China Gourmet!

Much better service than Philly Chinatown and amazing foods. Carts came over often and with fresh foods every time. Place was huge so there was not an issue of long wait. 
I've had dimsum all over and this restaurant is compatible to some of the best dimsum places in NYC chinatown. Selection was vast and everything tasted fresh, not too greasy, and well flavored. Our favorites were some of the staple dimsum items (chicken feet, steamed ribs, shrimp shumai, taro football looking thing). Beyond that, some of the more creative dishes are the fish stuffed in shisito pepper, shrimp stuffed in egg tofu. 

Overall, amazing experience and foods. I'll be bragging to everyone about this great find.

China Gourmet easily deserves all the hype that they've been receiving. The food is fantastic and fresh. The service is more efficient and (a little) less chaotic than their Chinatown counterparts. And the space is overall cleaner and running like a well-oiled machine. 

We ordered a plethora of typical dim sum dishes like their Har Gow, Siu Mai, Turnip Cakes, Shrimp-stuffed eggplant, steamed rice rolls, the sweet yellow cake, and so much more! I don't know what they're translated in english, so it's hard to describe LOL. 

You can tell that they make almost everything by scratch, which is such a nice touch. Every dish was flavorful and well done. We couldn't believe it. It's the best dim sum in the Philly area, and even better than the dim sum I had in NY the weekend after. Just upped my dim sum standards tremendously. 

An absolute Philly must-try.

Bonus points because of the large parking lot & surrounding street parking! & they accept credit cards!

Never order combo on this sheet. Although it says it's a "special price combo", they didn't put any prices on this shit because the majority of the dishes on this list only cost $12-13 for each, but they will charge you $48 for three of those dishes and won't let you know the exact prices. When you going back and argue that, the manager will assaulted you using aggressive language and told you it's all your fault instead theirs. "You are the one choosing these cheap dishes and you deserve this". Why didn't they put a price on this promotion sheet? Because they intend to trap some idiots who put so much trust on this restaurant. It is CHEATING. It's a fraud on the menu and a completely fraud on promotion.

Best dimsum place you can find in Philly. The service is really quick, and they accept cards and Apple Pay. It can be a longer drive from downtown, but it's totally worth it.

They offer menu with pictures, so it's very easy to order. I am always nervous when I get dimsum because of my broken Chinese, but it should not be your concern here. 

I realized the shumai and dumplings are not fresh compared to ones before Covid, but in general, they are still pretty good.

I ordered the beef lo mein and spring rolls on 1/15/21. Super easy pick up area and my food was ready within 20 minutes of ordering. Super helpful staff! Food was amazing. Delicious, perfectly seasoned and satisfying. 10/10 highly recommend and will dine here again.

Hadn't been since Covid. They haven't missed a beat as far as quality goes. Super friendly staff.
 Tables are 15-20 feet apart. We had the steamed oysters with ginger, Hong Kong style lobster, Peking duck, and Chinese broccoli with Chinese bacon. They were all excellent. Incredible quality and value. Can't wait to go back.

This place has definitely gone down in service this past year. I've always come here to grab food and this time around the lady who took my order literally had me sitting there for 45 minutes when I kept asking is that my food Togo on the table. She literally blew me off and no it's not a language barrier because she spoke English to me.

Greasy, expensive. The beef with scallion and ginger was swimming in grease, the beef tasted off. The eggplant in garlic sauce was also very greasy, unexpectedly had sugar in it, I could taste no garlic at all.
I expected so much more, given how costly these two entrees were.
I won't be ordering from here again. Don't really want the leftovers.
You live, you learn.

This has to be the best Chinese food spot in Philly. Ordered the General Tso's shrimp and it was cooked perfectly. Sauce was seasoned evenly and rice was delicious. Also had the spring rolls, so light and crispy.
The food was delicious! Since my old dim sum place in China town got a new cook it hasn't been the same. But I found a new spot

Ordered 2 combination platters through grubhub. It said combo platters come with fried rice and an egg roll. When the food arrived it was just 2 containers of beef and broccoli without the rice or egg rolls. I called the restaurant to ask what happened and was told "we don't sell combination platters" multiple times and then was hung up on. On top of the terrible service the food was completely flavorless and tasted like steamed beef and broccoli covered in sesame oil. Super disappointing and will definitely not be ordering again.

Not the most authentic dim sum you can get in US cuz none of them is authentic. but it is pretty good dim sum comparing to the dim sum food downtown AND finally a good dim sum restaurant in NE Philly.

It got the atmosphere of a dim sum restaurant right! It's huge and can fit lots people, and people going around showing and serving the food. 

It's good to bring in more competition as well
Has the best dim sum in northeast Philly area.  Ample parking for customer due to being right next to an Asian supermarket.

Went back recently and the quality has dipped. Since The owner, Selena and her husband, are focusing on their new venture on the Mainline it's not quite the same. We tried to order from their special menu in Chinese; however, they didn't honor some of the items and prices since the owner's not there. I also found a long piece of hair when I opened my naw mai gai (lotus leaf rice wrap) and it's def not mine since I have short hair. If the owner's not there, avoid this place.

Let me start by saying the food here is pretty good. I'm not one for dim sum, but I do really really like going here. Some notable dishes are their rice rolls, shrimp tofu, congee, calamari, pig custard buns, and Chinese fried lobster. 

BUT I have to say it's not the most inviting restaurant. It is always packed head to toe, it's loud, and the outside is riddled with cigarette butts. The inside is just a large floor with a giant karaoke tv in the middle. To the right is a bunch of fish that you can choose for your meal, which is never appealing. The poor guys are dying right next to you as you eat. It's extremely unpleasant.
If you are going to eat from here, I'd suggest ordering to go!

Also, I noted the lobster was very good--and it is--but I would be wary. The last time I had it, my lobster's stomach came out and there were blue plastic chunks in it. It was horrible and completely turned me off from seafood for a while. SO I recommend asking them to remove the stomach before serving!

business.name: Unit Su Vege
